content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 1h40
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli
  • @WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Joshua Nelson
I won't be able to make it, @Santiago Pastorino can you write up the check in?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , the weekly triage meeting is starting now
add a :wave: to show you’re here
thanks to @apiraino for preparing the agenda!
(or really all of wg-prioritization)

Let starts off with ~8 minutes for

Announcements
• :warning: next week June, 17th, release of Rust stable 1.53
( :warning: ? More like :tada: )
I thought :tada: next week :smile:
good point
don’t celebrate too soon
anyway, with the release come the trains pulling out of their respective stations
and so
• pnkfelix seeking review with quick turnaround (in time for cutting 1.54-beta tomorrow) on PR 85193
we’ll talk about that more with the nomination
if we get to that section
but I wanted to ensure I mentioned it up top in case we didn’t reach nominations
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "Don't steal the resolver when lowering HIR; instead store an immutable resolver in TyCtxt" compiler-team#437

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403
    • "LLVM plugin support in Rust" compiler-team#419
    • "Promote aarch64-apple-ios-sim to Tier 2" compiler-team#428
    • "Write text output files to stdout if options like -o - or --emit asm=- are provided" compiler-team#431

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Allow changing the bug report url for the ice hook" compiler-team#436

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.
Uh actually there was an MCP proposed & seconded yesterday. One sec.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Tracking issue for WebAssembly SIMD support" rust#74372
    • "Tracking Issue for VecDeque binary search functions" rust#78021
    • "Use try_reserve and panic in Vec's io::Write" rust#84612
    • "Show test type during prints" rust#84863
    • "rustc: Allow safe #[target_feature] on wasm" rust#84988
I don't see https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/438 in this list
That's it.
Transfer on-disk hash table implementation (odht crate) to rust-lang org compiler-team#438
okay
Since it is already in FCP, let's make sure folks get a chance to take a look
WG checkins

• @WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and @oli

    (both leads are on leave at the moment)

• @WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino and @Joshua Nelson

    Most notable changes

    • explain Miri engine vs Miri-the-tool #1134
    • Add more information about no_hash query modifier. #1133
    • Describe the difference of rustc_lint vs rustc_lint_defs. #1131
    • Document -Zunpretty=thir-tree #1128
    • Update coverage docs #1122

    Most notable WIPs

    • Update for merge of CrateDisambiguator into StableCrateId #1135
    • Document lang items #1119
    • Move "ctags" section into "Suggested Workflow" #1115
    • Document inert vs active attributes #1110
    • Explain the new valtree system for type level constants. #1097
    • rewrite ty.md #1057
    • improve glossary page #1053
also
• no steering meeting tomorrow (Friday 11 June)
but we do have one scheduled for next week (Friday 18 June), and I’m on the hook for preparing the doc for it
(and i really need to put up the Inside Rust blog post announcing the results of last Friday’s planning meeting. Hopefully today.)
Any other anouncements?

okay lets move on to

Backport Nominations
T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

• "Reachable statics have reachable initializers" rust#84549
    • opened by @tm
    • reviewed by @varkor
    • patch is already merged, fixes #84455, a P-medium ICE when crosscompiling
    • discussed last week
    • decision postponed (possibly decline the backport and let this patch land on next stable)
so I failed to follow through on my own self-assigned action item here
of figuring out the cases that worked and which ones didn’t work
I’m still inclined to let this ride trains
Ah wait tmiasko left comment
The patch seems very straightforward but given this has already been broken for two stable releases, I also don't feel a huge amount of pressure to rush it.
on issue #84455
I guess Ithink there are probably higher priority things to backport
e.g. there are some patches in flight that I think we do need for the next release
so, yeah
lets let it ride trains
next

• "Make copy/copy_nonoverlapping fn's again" rust#86003
    • opened and nominated for backport by @pnkfelix
    • addresses issue #84297, reverts PRs #81167 #81238, part of #82967, #83091 and parts of #79684.
(I am in midst of constructing a beta-targetted variant of this PR now. This is one of the ones I was thinking of as being higher priority backport.)
I did see someone left a :confused: on it
perhaps because the description is a soup of PR and issue numbers
IIRC that person is targeting embedded platforms and the current state of things leads to fairly bloated code for anything other than -O2. Some of these PRs were attempts to address that issue.
I see
We do hope to reland this stuff
I suppose I could have made that clearer. :)
though I’m not sure who is on the hook for resolving the questions around intristics vs lang items etc here
(i.e. who owns the decision)
anyway
I’m going to assert that this will be beta backported unless someone reaches out and tells me why it would be a mistake
So, beta backport approved

• "Disable the machine outliner by default" rust#86020
    • opened by @nagisa
    • no reviewer assigned
    • Fixes #85351, a P-critical micompilation on ARM-M arch
    • Fixing this involves a patch on LLVM, possibly will make it into LLVM 12.0.1
Does this mean that it will be in the stable release next week already?
that I think is the goal
is to get it in before the bug reaches stable
for all of these cases
ok
(the ones we’re approving, that is)
so we have to be extra careful
(I acknowledge that the risk is … not great…)
or rather
that we need to be aware
that we don’t have our usual buffer
and thus risk is inherently heightened
okay I just r+’ed PR #86020
(I am realizing that I need to start doing a pass over the agenda to bring it up to sync before each meeting.)
(e..g there are often discrepancies between the issue/PR notes and the current state, often due to changes over the course of the week…)
beta-backport approved for PR #86020

pnkfelix said:

(I am realizing that I need to start doing a pass over the agenda to bring it up to sync before each meeting.)

(or probably I should do that, like half an hour before the meeting)
@apiraino if you can spare the time for that, it would be awsome
but it also would’t be the worst thing in the world for me to familiarize myself with each agenda before the meeting
• No stable nominations for T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

  • No beta nominations for T-libs-impl this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

T-libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on T-libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 6 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 3 of those are unassigned
  • 77 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 50 of those are unassigned
  • 6 P-critical, 0 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 2 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 3 P-critical, 47 P-high, 87 P-medium, 10 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "ICE when reifying function pointers to copy / copy_nonoverlapping using an if" rust#84297
    • discussed in this Zulip thread
(we just discussed this, its the one that I’ve got a PR that I just beta-backport-approved)

• "Unstable fingerprints - what to do on beta (and stable)" rust#84970
    • Steering meeting lays plan to disable incr-comp on 1.53 (Zulip link from last week)
there’s an issue that is meant to remind us to forward port the RUSTC_FORCE_INCREMENTAL patch
where is that
"For 1.53, must fwd-port RUSTC_FORCE_INCREMENTAL from 1.52.1" #86004
so I think that will cover things
at least in the sense of getting 1.53 into releasable shape (update: w.r.t. incr-comp)
What about https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/85873?
I’ve been working under the assumption that everything would go back to the previous state for version 1.54
um
/me looks at #85873
and https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/85863 (which seems to be related)
these aren’t related to incr-comp?
right?
No
are you saying they should be listed on https://hackmd.io/1NeIcqXERkug9KItmB1TwQ?both
oh oh oh
I see
when I said

pnkfelix said:

at least in the sense of getting 1.53 into releasable shape
I only mean with respect to
no, they are p-critical and unassigned
incr-comp
ok
let me fix that
anyway
we can move along from rust#84970
i think

• "Miscompilation on ARM-M with nightly-2021-04-23" rust#85351
    • @nagisa authored patch #86020
    • LLVM patch in the pileline, too
which we just discussed
okay
and now

• "iter::Fuse is unsound with how specialization currently behaves around HRTB fn pointers" rust#85863
    • mentioned last week
    • opened by @Frank Steffahn
    • reporter suggests possible fixes, on Zulip some more thoughts
    • @Josh Triplett comments this issue will be discussed in a follow-up T-lang meeting
so
when was rust#85863 injected?
was it at same time as #85873 ?
these both seem like libs-impl issues
with some mix with T-lang
the main question I see for us right now
is do we need to take action right now to address this for the 1.53 release?
PR #83990 is at least one relevant PR here, that is initially in 1.53
are there others?
It looks like this can lead to unsound code, right?
I think that’s the claim, yeah
and a temporary fix is to remove the specialization?
that’s what I’m trying to understand
is what we need to remove
PR #83990 is one PR.
I believe this (#85873) was injected in 1.48 based on running the first example on rust.godbolt.org.
Oh wait, does PR #85874 cover everything that needs to be removed?
PR #85874 only says that it fixes #85873
is @Frank Steffahn here?
I guess issue #85863 explcitly says that Fuse is not covered by PR #85874
The language team seems to have discussed this. Is there a way to ping them here?
If they decided that this isn't a high priority they must have an idea what the implications are, right?
I wasn't a part of that conversation
and haven't had time to deeply investigate
But I think that the resolution was something like this:
• in the short term, the correct fix is to disable the optimizations by removing the specialized impl
• in the medium term, we should dig deeper and reassess how specialization and subtyping interact and if we can create another fix
• in the longer term, as we move to make progress on specialization, we should absolutely resolve this interaction (at least that's my personal opinion), as it seems like a real footgun
So the problem with that “short term” approach is that, IIUC, we cannot apply it to the Fuse problem?
yeah that's all pretty much accurate, from the meeting
That said, my one concern would be: are the specialized impls changing behavior or simply an optimization of sorts?
which I guess gets to your question about Fuse, @pnkfelix
also, for how long has this issue existed and how likely is it that it causes problems in the real world?
it seems to me like one obvious action item is that we should immediately back port PR #85874 to 1.53-beta

mw said:

also, for how long has this issue existed and how likely is it that it causes problems in the real world?

I'm trying to understand the exact problem, I haven't had time to dig in; my hunch is "a long time" and "unlikely"
the other question is "how big is the imapct of removing the specializations"

pnkfelix said:

it seems to me like one obvious action item is that we should immediately back port PR #85874 to 1.53-beta

That seems reasonable to me but it also looks like #85874 hasn't even been reviewed by the libs team yet. We should at least ping them to let them know we're doing that.
true
(digging a bit)
the code changes seem like they should all be inherently conservative, right?
(“conservative” in the sense of “should not cause behaviorial breakage.” At most, performance regression…)
I want to move ahead
I’ll take action item to resolve this
The precise question at hand is whether to backport?
probably by backporting PR #85874 after checking with representatives from libs team
it won’t resolve everything though
the Fuse thing is still open

nikomatsakis said:

The precise question at hand is whether to backport?

I think so
because the thing being backported
is fixing a problem injected on 1.53
(If i understand correctly)
This seems like an obvious step
I’m not really comfortable trying to take action beyond backporting PR #85874
as a stopgap measure
for the 1.53 release
What about this: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/85975?
yes
okay thank you
that’s the other PR I was hoping someone would find. :)
or wait
/me looks
is that the same bug?
I'm not sure
I need to better understand how PR #85874 and #85975 are related/differ
it seems like we need a PR removing this impl
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/0279cb11ed98bdc589c66572477fd27f1dd3e0ac/library/core/src/iter/adapters/fuse.rs#L411-L527
it seems like the perf impact is unlikely to be super high, but it could affect some optimizations or other things
but no one has proposed doing that so far? Why not?
I'm not aware of any reason
I could imagine this affecting (e.g.) autovectorized code
it introduces a branch
but I don't believe it would change behavior
Okay. I will take action item to look at all of these
Today, potentially this evening
obviously time is short. :sad:
Should we go ahead and beta-nominate #85975 so we don't lose track of it?
we’re almost out of meeting time. :sad:

Wesley Wiser said:

Should we go ahead and beta-nominate #85975 so we don't lose track of it?

sure
the discussion so far

pnkfelix said:

I need to better understand how PR #85874 and #85975 are related/differ

They don't seem to overlap
release is next week, so there won't be a meeting before then to approve it
has at least covered
both of the remaining critical issues

simulacrum said:

release is next week, so there won't be a meeting before then to approve it

right, we’re going to need to do something about that
Could we plan to convene at 10am EST tomorrow
duing the Friday meeting slot
to review?
under assumpton that by that time
I should have a proper description
and, with hope, actual code
Lets go with that for now, since I don’t see any other realistic option beyond a purely async approval process
/me will be offline tomorrow...
there are some libs-impl issues we haven’t had a chance to cdiscuss
@mw maybe I can try to loop you in later today? How many more hours are you available today?

libs-impl:

  • "lang_start in std/src/rt.rs is unsound in presence of panic payload that panics on drop" rust#86030
    • Unsoundness issue, @nagisa opened PR #86034, waiting for review

pnkfelix said:

mw maybe I can try to loop you in later today? How many more hours are you available today?

about 10 more minutes :)
ha h ahaha
but it's not like I bring any special expertise to the table here

pnkfelix said:

libs-impl:

  • "lang_start in std/src/rt.rs is unsound in presence of panic payload that panics on drop" rust#86030
    • Unsoundness issue, nagisa opened PR #86034, waiting for review

(I don’t see us addressing this for 1.53)
@mw okay

pnkfelix said:

but no one has proposed doing that so far? Why not?

This sounds like "Either change Fuse to not get into a UB-causing invalid state by such a coercion (which kills some (or perhaps most) of the optimization offered by Fuse)" described in #85863
hmm
well I think we probably need to err on the side of soundness here
we are way over time
instead of rushing through remaining agenda, and doing a poor job of it
I suggest we walk through the rest of it tomorrow
after we finish discussing these specialization things

pnkfelix said:

well I think we probably need to err on the side of soundness here

I agree with this, we don't have any evidence of major perf impact
also

I want to point again at:

  • "Re-add support for parsing (and pretty-printing) inner-attributes in match body" rust#85193
    - see announcements
    - opened by @pnkfelix
    - re-adds support for match EXPR { #![inner] ARM_1 ARM_2 ... } to sidestep breakage from PR 83312
    - lang team FCP in process; not end of world if review+landing doesn't happen before 1.54-beta is cut on Friday (tomorrow), but it is nice to avoid backports
Okay, thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!!!
I guess this meeting did end up being a lot more :caution: than :tada: !!!

pnkfelix said:

pnkfelix said:

libs-impl:

  • "lang_start in std/src/rt.rs is unsound in presence of panic payload that panics on drop" rust#86030
    • Unsoundness issue, nagisa opened PR #86034, waiting for review

(I don’t see us addressing this for 1.53)

Yeah, this "UB" is fairly obscure and in some ways one we imposed upon ourselves. In practice I think the actual behaviour is mild enough that there is no need to backport any changes to fix this issue.
I never beta-nominated the PR for that specific reason.

Ah, I didn’t see the ping. Answering a few questions after the fact:

mw said:

pnkfelix said:

I need to better understand how PR #85874 and #85975 are related/differ

They don't seem to overlap

This is indeed the case. #85975 is fixing #85969 which is a (not necessarily easy to hit) a behavioral regression introduced in beta 1.53, but no unsoundness. #85874 is about a soundness issue (#85873) that’s already present in stable, but not as old as the issue involving Fuse. That one (#85863) is, IIRC, as old as FusedIterator itself.

The only connection between #85874 and #85975 is that they both involve TrustedRandomAccess.

pnkfelix said:

but no one has proposed doing that so far? Why not?

The reason might be the documentation of FusedIterator:

Note: In general, you should not use FusedIterator in generic bounds if you need a fused iterator. Instead, you should just call Iterator::fuse() on the iterator. If the iterator is already fused, the additional Fuse wrapper will be a no-op with no performance penalty.

Thus, removing the specialization for Fuse pretty-much kills the entire premise of FusedIterator, in a way.

Draft for next week's agenda is available at:
https://hackmd.io/YIIP5vCnSjOYogzRSlJ9MQ?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser
  • @WG-llvm by @nagisa (last update)

pnkfelix said:

after we finish discussing these specialization things

@T-compiler/meeting one more thing: at what time will this meeting take place? I'd like to be there too (if I don't have other work meetings in the way) , I may have to update some issues thereafter
@apiraino I was assuming it would be during the steering meeting slot. 2021-06-11T10:00:00-04:00
